messageBody:
> Indeed. Not only that, as a component user, I find that Javadoc is
> sufficient to my purpose most of the time. It is rare that I need the
> level of detail that a class' contract gives me. When I do need it, I
> want it in a formal notation, since natural languages are ambiguous. At
> that point, Java code is the preferred formal notation, since Java is the
> language I program in the most. I'll accept Smalltalk and muddle through
> with Ruby. Any way you slice it, I wanna see code. The best code is
> self-verifying executing code. Sounds like a JUnit test. :)

What I think would be cool is Compaq's ESC Java
(http://research.compaq.com/SRC/esc/) modified in two ways:

- Make the annotation language part of javadoc
- Make the license usable (currently it's very limiting.)

Basically then you could have compile-time "design by contract" tests in
Java, written in Javadoc where they could be incorporated into the
documentation.

Another interesting verification tool (which I've done some work on/with)
is Java PathFinder - http://ase.arc.nasa.gov/visser/jpf/. It does runtime
model checking on real java code...

Both of these tools are researchy and experimental, I'd love to see the
methods they employ get pushed into a mainstream tool.

Later,
Dale
